snippet: A German philosopher, Bettina Stangneth, explores the voluminous memoirs of Adolf Eichmann, and her country’s reluctance to prosecute him.
abstract: Bettina Stangneth book Eichmann Before Jerusalem: The Unexamined Life of a Mass Murderer portrays Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann as independent-minded and passionate member of Third Reich who was instrumental in bringing about Holocaust; depiction counters image of Eichmann as banal figure who was unaware of enormity of his actions, presented in Hannah Arendt book Eichmann in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: A German philosopher, Bettina Stangneth, explores the voluminous memoirs of Adolf Eichmann, and her country’s reluctance to prosecute him.

headline.main: Book Portrays Eichmann as Evil, but Not Banal
headline.print_headline: Book Portrays Genocidal Nazi as Evil, but Not Banal

keywords.value: Eichmann Before Jerusalem: The Unexamined Life of a Mass Murderer (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works
